paragraphs.name: 7bee
paragraphs.text:
I haven’t been writing as much, lately. When I do write, I’m afraid to share. I used to be brazen with a pen. I sometimes possess an amazing capacity to speak without inhibition — and to do it with conviction, despite my insecurities. But not lately. Lately, I filter everything through the part of my head that anticipates reactions and counter reactions and then reactions to counter reactions. I’ve been letting the comments get to me. The comments, the tweets, the emails, the mentions, the blog posts, the abuse. I say let, but it doesn’t feel much like a choice. People tell me it’s a choice. They say: look at all the nice things people are saying. Think about that. Don’t think about that. Don’t let them win. Don’t let it get to you. That’s what they want. 
 
 I’ve been trying to think about what I want. I guess what I’ve always sought is the ability to be at home in myself — to not feel like I am sitting in a chair surrounded by the fortress of my body, living a life that no one is willing to connect with. I write to not feel like a ghost. Or, to tell the other ghosts that there is someone else haunting her couch, and sometimes the world, wailing a tune that harmonizes with theirs. I am vulnerable. I am not some Strong Black Woman archetype who has made peace with the bad parts of her life and is trying to save the world with them, now. I am just a person with a borrowed laptop, trying to prove to myself that I am real, that the things that have happened to me are real. 
 
I am spilling my guts here. I am unearthing buried things. I do not have a lot of this shit processed. I don’t know that I ever will. I am in a lifelong struggle with an inner voice that is cruel and degrading and destructive. It is lofty enough to shut that part of me out. It is doubly difficult to shut out the voices of strangers echoing the awfulness. An angry mob arrives in my inbox like an alarm blaring: You are not real. Your suffering is not real. All the bad things were good. You should be grateful for your trauma. Shut up. You are too broken to function. We feel sorry for the people who know you. You have fucked up your life. We do not care. We do not care.

paragraphs.name: ee4b
paragraphs.text:
And I let it get to me. 
 
When I etch out a plea for water, my blood as ink, and I cast that note out to sea, and someone sends back a bottle of vomit and shit– well, I let it get to me. Yup, I know it’s the internet. Yup, I know it’s par for the course. I know that writing about the rights to my humanity as a Black woman is controversial. I know that people are too full for compassion. I know about cognitive dissonance, willful ignorance. But it is exhausting. The malice. The scorn. It’s exhausting.

paragraphs.name: bea8
paragraphs.text: It’s okay to keep the door closed for as long as you need to steel your resolve. It’s okay if you don’t have any resolve right now. They don’t win by willing you to quit. They win by convincing you that you don’t deserve tenderness. Be tender with yourself. Take care of yourself. Take a break. Take time. Take privacy. Take what you need. Don’t take abuse as a standard for the industry, as something to accept. The standard should not be martyrdom. You deserve protection.

paragraphs.name: c3e9
paragraphs.text: And it gets to me. It gets to me. I can not ignore it. My feet don’t moonwalk over it. I am trudging through the shit. So I’m writing this short piece for all of the people like me who are beating themselves up, who feel like they’re dysfunctional, like there’s something wrong with them for not being able to detach from it it, not being able to ignore it. It’s okay if it gets to you. You are a person. You are not an impenetrable wall. If you can’t take any more of it, it’s okay to stop sharing, to take a break, to preserve yourself. If you can’t stop writing, it’s okay to write impersonally.

paragraphs.name: 7bee
paragraphs.text:
I haven’t been writing as much, lately. When I do write, I’m afraid to share. I used to be brazen with a pen. I sometimes possess an amazing capacity to speak without inhibition — and to do it with conviction, despite my insecurities. But not lately. Lately, I filter everything through the part of my head that anticipates reactions and counter reactions and then reactions to counter reactions. I’ve been letting the comments get to me. The comments, the tweets, the emails, the mentions, the blog posts, the abuse. I say let, but it doesn’t feel much like a choice. People tell me it’s a choice. They say: look at all the nice things people are saying. Think about that. Don’t think about that. Don’t let them win. Don’t let it get to you. That’s what they want.

I guess what I’ve always sought is the ability to be at home in myself — to not feel like I am sitting in a chair surrounded by the fortress of my body, living a life that no one is willing to connect with. I write to not feel like a ghost. Or, to tell the other ghosts that there is someone else haunting her couch, and sometimes the world, wailing a tune that harmonizes with theirs. I am vulnerable. I am not some Strong Black Woman archetype who has made peace with the bad parts of her life and is trying to save the world with them, now. I am just a person with a borrowed laptop, trying to prove to myself that I am real, that the things that have happened to me are real. 
 
I am spilling my guts here. I am unearthing buried things. I do not have a lot of this shit processed. I don’t know that I ever will. I am in a lifelong struggle with an inner voice that is cruel and degrading and destructive. It is lofty enough to shut that part of me out. It is doubly difficult to shut out the voices of strangers echoing the awfulness. An angry mob arrives in my inbox like an alarm blaring: You are not real. Your suffering is not real. All the bad things were good. You should be grateful for your trauma. Shut up. You are too broken to function. We feel sorry for the people who know you. You have fucked up your life. We do not care. We do not care.

241ca41bc60c.title: "I am just a person with a borrowed laptop, trying to prove to myself that I am real, that the…

paragraphs.text: "I am just a person with a borrowed laptop, trying to prove to myself that I am real, that the things that have happened to me are real."
That just went up on a 3 x 5 card on my wall.

virtuals.subtitle: That just went up on a 3 x 5 card on my wall.

content.subtitle: That just went up on a 3 x 5 card on my wall.

paragraphs.text: I second this. Thaddeus Howze, your piece really touched me. I don’t always read the comments, because I’m trying to avoid the bad ones. I’m a bit late, but this was really incredible and kind of you. And now, you too, H. Nemesis Nyx. Your words are deeply felt. I need y’all like you say I’m needed. ❤
paragraphs.name: cd65

paragraphs.text: You are gifted. Prophets were abused or feared when they shared their gifts. Not everyone is supposed to accept your gift. Not everyone can understand your gift but those whose spirit is blessed to receive it, understand it, and through that understanding share and feel your pain. Don’t close off your gift, don’t hide your candle under a bush. Set the world afire instead. I look forward to your next blaze…
paragraphs.name: a5bf

f36ce0fb28f3.title: You are vulnerable, Dominique and that’s why I read you.

paragraphs.text: You are vulnerable, Dominique and that’s why I read you. I don’t want to read someone strong because I want to read someone real. I think you and your words are beautiful. I am sorry that you have found any other response. It happens.
paragraphs.name: ef7f

paragraphs.text: You are very wise. Be kind to yourself. Take a break. Take care of you and if you can…
paragraphs.name: 171a

virtuals.subtitle: You are very wise. Be kind to yourself. Take a break. Take care of you and if you can, build a community that doesn’t take shots at…

content.subtitle: You are very wise. Be kind to yourself. Take a break. Take care of you and if you can, build a community that doesn’t take shots at…

cdb2007f6c31.title: There is grace in vulnerability, as much as it hurts.

paragraphs.text: There is grace in vulnerability, as much as it hurts. And the decision to let the pain or fear or shadow out means it does not fester in you as it does in others. It makes room for joy.
paragraphs.name: dee0

paragraphs.text: The viciousness gets to us all — so much so that some of us never utter a word.
paragraphs.name: ddde

virtuals.subtitle: The viciousness gets to us all — so much so that some of us never utter a word.

paragraphs.name: d0dc

paragraphs.text: I wish I could have articulated my desire to support the writer you addressed here, half as well as you have done…

eb2967b1d76b.title: I feel you! Get your peace but don’t give up your space😊

paragraphs.text: I feel you! Get your peace but don’t give up your space😊
paragraphs.name: b5de

paragraphs.text: Thank you for your honsety. This came at the perfect time for me. I too am struggling with making myself vulnerable and letting “them” change the way I feel about myself, letting “them” make me feel small, letting “them” get to me. Sometimes I think I’m so tough, but then when I allow critical words to penetrate my heart, I know inside I am just a ball of mush. Thank you so much for sharing!
paragraphs.name: 4b5d

80709f1f3a06.title: I feel this piece may be too beautifully poignant & well written for this type of response, but the…

paragraphs.text: I feel this piece may be too beautifully poignant & well written for this type of response, but the first thought that came to my mind upon completion of the read was YASSS QUEEN. You hit the nail on the head. You hit that nail so hard that it popped all the way through the drywall & into the next room. Bravo, girl.
paragraphs.name: 051b

8cd5c734a73f.title: Thank you so much for this.

paragraphs.text: Thank you so much for this. As a woman who writes personal essays and gets regular hate mail, this was an encouraging and valuable pick-me-up, a reminder that this sort of treatment is abuse, and that abused people need rest and self-care. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
paragraphs.name: eab6

416dda0665be.title: If the voices inside don’t know how to shut up, just ask them, do you really know me?

paragraphs.text: If the voices inside don’t know how to shut up, just ask them, do you really know me? Me! The me I am that is the best me of the whole entire universe, me. That me, what will you say to that me!
paragraphs.name: b0cb

paragraphs.text: And then listen for them to speak, they’ll say nothing, nothing at all.
paragraphs.name: b52a

virtuals.subtitle: And then listen for them to speak, they’ll say nothing, nothing at all.

content.subtitle: And then listen for them to speak, they’ll say nothing, nothing at all.

508da113c8f4.title: I haven’t read any of your other pieces… but I love this one.

paragraphs.text: I haven’t read any of your other pieces… but I love this one. Keep keeping it real. I want to hear your voice.

7a45515f726d.title: As I said, fuck that shit.

paragraphs.text: As I said, fuck that shit.
paragraphs.name: 166a

paragraphs.text: you are real. I bear witness to your realness and your struggles and your triumphs. I see all of it, and I see you. thank you for sharing your vulnerability with us, and in doing so encouraging us to keep living.
paragraphs.name: 54f9

70106ba08abe.title: You are one of my favorite writers and people. Please protect and value yourself.

paragraphs.text: You are one of my favorite writers and people. Please protect and value yourself.
paragraphs.name: 235a

5f90cd4c7d23.title: Even if you aren’t a writer by trade, this post resonates with all who create and share.

paragraphs.text: Even if you aren’t a writer by trade, this post resonates with all who create and share. We all get criticized and bombarded by negativity at various levels. Your words communicate that struggle to stand tall. Thank you for sharing your struggle, your story. You’ve given me hope.
This is me right now 😢
paragraphs.name: 20eb

paragraphs.text: Well done.
paragraphs.name: e20b

106079cc32ce.title: Frankly I ignore all comments in my blog or everywhere else I post.

paragraphs.text: Frankly I ignore all comments in my blog or everywhere else I post. The comments section in any community is a cesspool of assholes. And what’s what they feed on: Hate.
paragraphs.name: 9cbd

c89bdae29410.title: Your words resonate beyond the community of black women writers.

paragraphs.text: Your words resonate beyond the community of black women writers. Thank you for talking about that nasty inner voice some of us have to fight so that we can keep writing.
paragraphs.name: fcdd

paragraphs.text: Thank you!
paragraphs.name: d975

paragraphs.text: Get Yourself a Justice League
paragraphs.name: 01b5

paragraphs.text: Never let them see you sweat.
paragraphs.name: 1bde

content.subtitle: Never let them see you sweat.

86e7ff508762.title: Thank you so much for this. I needed it today.

paragraphs.text: Thank you so much for this. I needed it today.
paragraphs.name: 7edc

122b856a1e98.title: Your rights and the right to write about your experience is in no way controversial, don’t you dare…

paragraphs.text: Your rights and the right to write about your experience is in no way controversial, don’t you dare believe the lie of ignorance falling from the lips of those who would hide in the shadows of hate and fear, please. People do not need excuses made for them so they can continue to be selfish and ignorant, they need their asses kicked into reality. You will get through this Dominique, keep doing what your doing.
paragraphs.name: 1f17

fab578ba977b.title: This is so sad to me.

paragraphs.text: This is so sad to me. I don’t know what it is like to be attacked on this scale, by strangers, but even one emotional abuser can cause damage if their victim is vulnerable. Right now you are wounded and need to take care of your self, self being the key word. Be tender with your wounded self. We all deserve tenderness; don’t let them convince you otherwise.
paragraphs.name: ae7e
